SEG.ORIGINAL_TEXT: Paris shooting: Hero police officer who begged for his life was married MUSLIM
A MUSLIM police officer begged for his life as masked gunmen shot him to death
on the streets of Paris as part of the Charlie Hebdo magazine massacre.
Chilling footage of the attack on the satirical magazine offices shows Ahmed
Merabet on the ground and begging for mercy as he is killed by a gunshot to the
After being shot the first time, the gunmen wearing balaclavas and wielding
Kalashnikov rifles are seeing running past the police officer - who had his
hands up in surrender - before they shoot him again point-blank as he lies on
the pavement outside the offices in the 11th arrondissement of Paris.
Mr Merabet, 42, is reportedly said to have asked his killers "Do you want to
kill me?" before they allegedly replied: "Okay chief."
He is survived by his wife.
Mr Merabet was one of 12 killed in the horrifying "terrorist" attack, which
claimed the lives of a second police officer and 10 others, mostly journalists
The police bodyguard of Charlie Hebdo editor Stephane Charbonnier, Franck
Brinsolaro was also shot dead by the attackers.
Mr Brinsolaro was sitting in the editorial room alongside Mr Charbonnier when
the gunmen burst in to the room and opened fire killing several cartoonists.
He is survived by his wife and two children.
Tributes continue to pour in on social networking sites for the two police
officers killed in the line of duty.
One Twitter user wrote: "RIP Ahmed Merabet, French policeman, murdered
While Alan Mendoza said: "Important to note that amid the carnage today a brave
Muslim policeman was murdered by those claiming to represent Islam."
While thousands paid tribute to Mr Merabet by tweeting the hashtag #JeSuisAhmed
which trend on the social networking site.
It follows on from the #JeSuisCharlie Twitter campaign, which has seen people
across the globe show their solidarity with the publication at the centre of
the attack by posting the phrase.
Editor-in-chief Mr Charbonnier, widely known by his pen name Charb, had
received death threats in the past and was under police protection ahead of the
According to reports, the 47-year-old was in an editorial meeting with the
other victims at the magazine's central Paris offices when the masked attackers
entered and opened fire with Kalashnikov assault rifles.
They reportedly shouted: "The Prophet has been avenged" and "Allahu akbar!"
Mr Charbonnier was one of the magazine's top cartoonists as well as a stout
He was in charge when the paper's offices were destroyed by a firebomb in 2011
after it had proposed inviting the Prophet Muhammad to be a guest editor.
He was the weekly magazine's most recent editor, after taking post in 2012.
Mr Charbonnier, who once said "a drawing has never killed anyone", had been
included on a Wanted Dead Or Alive For Crimes Against Islam article published
in 2013 by Inspire, the terrorist propaganda magazine published by al-Qaeda.
Cartoonists Georges Wolinski, Jean Cabut, Bernard 'Tignous' Verlhac and
Philippe Honor, as well as economist Bernard Maris are also among the dead.
As well as magazine copy editor Mustapha Ourrad, columnist and analyst Elsa
Cayat a columnist and analyst, Frederic Boisseau, a building maintenance
worker and biennial Carnet de Voyage in Clermont-Ferrand festival founder
The gunmen are said to have sought out the journalists by name, according to
Mr Wolinski, 80, who lived in Paris, was married twice, first to Jacqueline
Saba, with whom he had two children, Frederica and Natacha.
He then married Maryse Bachere in 1971 and they together had one daughter
He had been drawing cartoons since the 1960s.
He was born in Tunisia and moved to France as a schoolboy. By age 26, he was
working for satirical magazine Hara-Kiri, considered a forerunner of Charlie
He was awarded the Legion of Honour, France's highest decoration, in 2005.
Mr Cabut, 76, also known as 'Cabu' was the magazine's lead cartoonist having
established himself as one of France's best-known cartoonists over a career
He served in the French military during the Algerian war for independence in
the late 1950s, and later drew cartoons for several publications.
One of Cabut's recurring characters was the Grande Duduche, a skinny, blond
schoolboy bearing some resemblance to Cabut himself.
Cabut's son, Mano Solo, a prominent singer and composer, died in 2010 at age 46.
Mr Verlhac, 57, who drew cartoons under the name 'Tignous', was born in Paris
in 1957 and published his first works in 1980.
He was a member of a group of artists called Cartoonists for Peace and also
belonged to the Press Judiciare, an association of French journalists covering
He sent his last drawing - a self-portrait wishing Happy New Year - to the
association the night before his death. It was posted on the group's website
Mr Maris, 68, gained prominence as both an economist and a journalist.
He wrote a weekly column in Charlie Hebdo called "Uncle Bernard," was a regular
commentator on economics for the France Inter radio network, and taught
economics at a branch of the University of Paris.
He also was a member of the General Council of the Bank of France.
"Bernard Maris was a man of heart, of culture and of great tolerance," the
bank's president, Christian Noyer said in a statement. "We will miss him very
Political caricaturist Mr Honore was reportedly the fifth Charlie Hebdo
cartoonist to be killed in the attack.
It was his drawing, depicting Isis leader Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi offering his
best wishes for the new year - "and especially good health!" - that was the
last ever published on Charlie's Twitter account just moments before the
Local media have reported that the 73-year-old was not killed immediately but
succumbed to his injuries after the attack.
Born in 1941, Mr Honore was a self-taught cartoonist who was first published at
the age of 16 in the newspaper Sud-Ouest. He had been involved in Charlie since
Meanwhile Mr Renaud was one of two founders of the biennial Carnet de Voyage in
Those he worked with at the festival are "in mourning", according to a
France Bleu in Auvergne has reported Mr Renaud had gone to visit Charlie
Hebdo's offices with another member of his organisation, Gerard Gaillard, who
According to France Bleu, the pair had come to visit Jean Cabut, who was a
guest of honour at last year's event.
Ms Cayat, was a psychiatrist and psychoanalyst and the only woman killed in the
She wrote a twice-monthly column for Charlie Hebdo entitled "Charlie Divan" -
"Couch" - and published essays on relations between men and women and sexuality.
Mr Boisseau had worked for French catering and site facilities company Sodexo
He was reportedly a 42-year-old father-of two.
"All of us share the belief that it is intolerable that one of our colleagues
has lost his life in such tragic and injust circumstances, and for a cause so
contrary to our values," Sodexo group director-general Michel Landel said in a
Minutes after the attack, two men strolled out to a black car waiting below,
calmly firing on a police officer, with one gunman shooting him in the head as
he writhed on the ground, according to video and a man who watched in fear from
Charlie Hebdo has launched a series of attacks on Islamic extremism and the
last tweet on its profile page @Charlie_Hebdo_, sent around an hour before the
shootings, included a satirical cartoon of Islamic State leader Abu Bakr
No group has yet claimed responsibility for the atrocity and a massive manhunt
has been launched for three gunman on the loose after the deadly terror attack.
